Chapter 10 When Your Code Doesn’t Work: Seeking Help from your Peers 10.1 Help People Help You 10.2 A Reproducible Example or a “reprex” 10.3 Other Helpful Resources

Chapter 10 When Your Code Doesn’t Work: Seeking Help from your Peers If you’re having trouble using a function or package, or getting the syntax correct, 9 times out of 10 the answers you are seeking have already been asked and answered on-line: RStudio Community Stack Overflow. You can search using the [r] tag. Google If you can’t find the answer, there are a few useful tools to help you ask a question on-line or from your peers in bcgov. bcgov Yammer channels (e.g. R, Data Science CoP) bcgov RocketChat #rstats channel 10.1 Help People Help You Whan starting a conversation about code, there are a few things that when included make that conversation more efficient and pleasant for everyone: some sample data the not-working code (with comments, white-space, indents == make it easy to read) information about your computing environment, like your operating system, version of R, the packages you have loaded ?dput Will dump the data you’re working with into a format so that it can be copy and pasted by anyone else into their R session. library(readr) cats <- read_csv(file = "data/feline-data.csv") dput(cats) cats <- structure(list(coat = c("calico", "black", "tabby"), weight = c(2.1, 5, 3.2), likes_string = c(1, 0, 1)), class = c("spec_tbl_df", "tbl_df", "tbl", "data.frame"), row.names = c(NA, -3L), spec = structure(list( cols = list(coat = structure(list(), class = c("collector_character", "collector")), weight = structure(list(), class = c("collector_double", "collector")), likes_string = structure(list(), class = c("collector_double", "collector"))), default = structure(list(), class = c("collector_guess", "collector")), skip = 1), class = "col_spec")) sessionInfo() ## R version 3.6.1 (2019-07-05) ## Platform: x86_64-apple-darwin15.6.0 (64-bit) ## Running under: macOS Mojave 10.14.6 ## ## Matrix products: default ## BLAS: /Library/Frameworks/R.framework/Versions/3.6/Resources/lib/libRblas.0.dylib ## LAPACK: /Library/Frameworks/R.framework/Versions/3.6/Resources/lib/libRlapack.dylib ## ## locale: ## [1] en_CA.UTF-8/en_CA.UTF-8/en_CA.UTF-8/C/en_CA.UTF-8/en_CA.UTF-8 ## ## attached base packages: ## [1] stats graphics grDevices utils datasets methods base ## ## loaded via a namespace (and not attached): ## [1] compiler_3.6.1 magrittr_1.5 bookdown_0.13 tools_3.6.1 ## [5] htmltools_0.3.6 rstudioapi_0.10 yaml_2.2.0 Rcpp_1.0.2 ## [9] stringi_1.4.3 rmarkdown_1.15 knitr_1.25 stringr_1.4.0 ## [13] xfun_0.9 digest_0.6.21 evaluate_0.14 Will print out your current version of R, as well as any packages you have loaded. This can be useful for others to help reproduce and debug your issue. 10.2 A Reproducible Example or a “reprex” reprex: Prepare reprexes for posting to GitHub issues, StackOverflow, Slack snippets, or email and so on. demo library(readr) library(dplyr) ## ## Attaching package: 'dplyr' ## The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': ## ## filter, lag ## The following objects are masked from 'package:base': ## ## intersect, setdiff, setequal, union library(ggplot2) cats <- read_csv(file = "data/feline-data.csv") ## Parsed with column specification: ## cols( ## coat = col_character(), ## weight = col_double(), ## likes_string = col_double() ## ) cats %>% select(coat, weight) %>% ggplot(aes(x = coat, y = weight)) + geom_col() # Make bar chart - this does not work? cats %>% select(coat, weight) %>% ggplot(aes(x = coat, y = weight)) %>% geom_col() ## Error: `mapping` must be created by `aes()` ## Did you use %>% instead of +? You have read the error message but it was not helpful, you used ?ggplot2, and looked on-line and I still cannot find an answer. Maybe someone in the bcgovR community knows? We need to invest a bit of time making the buggy code shareable – the easier it is for someone to run the code, the easier – and likely faster – someone might be able to provide some help. If the data is shareable (e.g. available in the B.C. Data Catalogue with appropriate licence, publicly available) then we can use dput(): library(readr) library(dplyr) library(ggplot2) cats <- structure(list(coat = c("calico", "black", "tabby"), weight = c(2.1, 5, 3.2), likes_string = c(1, 0, 1)), class = c("spec_tbl_df", "tbl_df", "tbl", "data.frame"), row.names = c(NA, -3L), spec = structure(list( cols = list(coat = structure(list(), class = c("collector_character", "collector")), weight = structure(list(), class = c("collector_double", "collector")), likes_string = structure(list(), class = c("collector_double", "collector"))), default = structure(list(), class = c("collector_guess", "collector")), skip = 1), class = "col_spec")) cats %>% select(coat, weight) %>% ggplot(aes(x = coat, y = weight)) %>% geom_col() ## Error: `mapping` must be created by `aes()` ## Did you use %>% instead of +? If the data is not shareable, you can use some built in data: library(readr) library(dplyr) library(ggplot2) cats %>% select(coat, weight) %>% ggplot(aes(x = coat, y = weight)) %>% geom_col() ## Error: `mapping` must be created by `aes()` ## Did you use %>% instead of +? ?datasets #built in datasets ?starwars #ships with dplyr # View(starwars) starwars %>% select(name, height) %>% ggplot(aes(x = name, y = height)) %>% geom_col() ## Error: `mapping` must be created by `aes()` ## Did you use %>% instead of +? 10.3 Other Helpful Resources RStudio cheat sheets Quick R Cookbook for R
